item.title: [SPR-2730] JMSException conversion in JmsUtils.convertJmsAccessException()
item.description:
When using the JmsTemplate to send a JMS Message and a javax.jms.JMSException is thrown by the container Spring attempts to convert the javax.jms.JMSException to its own org.springframework.jms.JmsException. However in the conversion the class name that is generated is org.springframework.jms.JMSException (note JMS is uppercase). This is due to the java.beans.Introspector decapitalize method that gets called.

Naturally this causes a ClassNotFound exception. While this is handled in the code...

//
logger.debug("Couldn't resolve JmsException class [" + longName + "]", ex2);
//

I think this is not what is expected. Full stack trace included for reference.

comments.comment:
This is a bit odd since we have a superclass-equals-JMSException check there... So the translation should only be attempted for direct subclasses of "javax.jms.JMSException" in the first place. For any other exception class, an UncategorizedJmsException should get thrown straight away, without any such debug logging. Could you please check what exact class the original exception was? Is there maybe some WebLogic-specific exception class that is named JMSException (in whatever package)?

Juergen

Hi Juergen,

if (JMSException.class.equals(ex.getClass().getSuperclass())) {
Must be true as we get the log message produced by code
logger.debug("Couldn't resolve JmsException class [" + longName + "]", ex2);

String shortName = ClassUtils.getShortName(ex.getClass().getName());
Believe shortName will contain JMSException NOT JmsException. This is the root of the problem and gives the class not found.

Hope my analysis is correct.
James

The strange part here is indeed that the short class name is "JMSException": This means that there is a direct subclass of "javax.jms.JMSException" of which the short name is also "JMSException"... maybe "weblogic.jms.JMSException" or the like? Would be interesting to know the fully-qualified class name there...

In any case, I do plan to refine the translation process there, also to handle subclasses of the standard JMS exception classes in a specific fashion (rather than turning them into UncategorizedJmsException).

Juergen

I eventually decided to reimplement the entire JMSException translation to handle subclasses of standard JMSExceptions in a specific fashion as well. There is no reflection-based translation anymore now: It has been replaced with straight instanceof-based translation.

Juergen
